div.div: 'It's a miracle anything about this ecosystem works at all.'

#‚Äã637 ‚Äî May 4, 2023
Read on the Web
Psst.. if you're wondering about the context of today's subject line, see the first ‚ö°Ô∏è In Brief.
JavaScript‚Ñ¢ Weekly
Angular v16 Released ‚Äî With the ‚Äúbiggest release since the initial rollout of Angular‚Äù, v16 of the extensive framework introduces a preview of a new signals-based reactivity model (a.k.a. Angular Signals), RxJS interop, improved SSR and hydration, experimental esbuild support, Jest unit testing, and more. Minko Gechev
üí° See the end of this issue where Minko makes the case for Angular in 2023.
Qwik Reaches v1.0 ‚Äî In ‚Äúother big JS frameworks that aren‚Äôt React‚Äù news, Qwik has hit a major milestone too. Qwik‚Äôs selling point remains performance through serving up as little code as needed on initial page load. ‚ÄúThink of it as streaming for your JavaScript,‚Äù they say. Nonetheless, you get the JSX, directory-based routing, and middleware options you may be familiar with. Qwik Team
Bring Your Team from Zero to 100 Deploys a Day ‚Äî Curious about how companies such as Atlassian, Google, and Netflix deploy hundreds of times a day? What strategies do they use to achieve efficiency? This guide provides you with tips and tricks on how these companies scaled their deployments so that you can do the same. Sleuth sponsor
üá©üá™ The German Government Invests in JavaScript ‚Äî Sort of. Germany‚Äôs Sovereign Tech Fund has made a big investment in the OpenJS Foundation, a Linux Foundation project that supports the JS ecosystem and hosts projects including Electron, jQuery, Node.js, Node-RED, and webpack. Robin Ginn (OpenJS Foundation)
‚ö°Ô∏è IN BRIEF: Mark Erikson (Redux) wrote a Twitter thread about üê¶ things he has to keep in mind when publishing a library in 2023 ‚Äì it's a lot. He summarized: "It's a miracle anything about this ecosystem works at all." We plan to write about this in a future issue, but Deno KV is a new in beta key value store now baked into both the Deno runtime (as of Deno 1.33) and available in the cloud. The latest VS Code release is out, with improvements to the terminal, new default dark and light color themes, support for profile templates, a built-in color picker, and support for strict nulls for JavaScript in HTML script blocks. A roundup of what's new in the Svelte world. Node.js can now run on every major browser engine as WebContainers now run on Safari, iOS and iPadOS, as well as Chrome and Firefox. Live demo. Chrome is to replace the üîí icon in the location bar with a vaguer 'tune' icon. Popular app hosting platform Vercel has added three new first-class storage options for files, Postgres databases, and Redis-like key/value stores.
RELEASES: Capacitor 5.0 ‚Äì Build cross-platform native PWAs. Node.js v20.1.0 (Current) pnpm 8.4 ‚Äì Efficient package manager. React Native macOS 0.71 Electron 24.2
üìí Articles & Tutorials
A Practical Guide to Not Blocking the Event Loop ‚Äî Engines typically run JavaScript in a single thread with an event loop. However, the nature of mixing synchronous and asynchronous tasks, along with the increasing popularity of workers for running code on separate threads, makes the landscape harder to navigate than it used to be. Slava Knyazev
The Interactive Guide to Rendering in React ‚Äî An interactive, illustrated guide exploring why, when and how React renders, complete with a series of well thought out animations. Tyler McGinnis
Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future ‚Äî 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, jest, karma, jasmine, and more. Wallaby.js sponsor
The const 'Deception' ‚Äî If the exact role of const has confused you in the past, this will be a handy primer that digs into the distinction between ‚Äúassignment‚Äù and ‚Äúmutation‚Äù in JavaScript. Josh W Comeau
Write Better CSS by Borrowing Ideas from JS? ‚Äî A curious look at taking best practices from the JavaScript space for writing better CSS. Yaphi Berhanu
Crafting the Next.js Website ‚Äî The official Next.js site is impressive, but what went into it? One of the designers shares some of the implementation details which aren‚Äôt particularly React-y but may prove inspiring to you. Rauno Freiberg
Exposing a Rust Library to Node with NAPI-RS
John Murray
üõ† Code & Tools
date-fns 2.30: A Modern Date Utility Library ‚Äî It‚Äôs been a couple of years since we linked to this ‚Äúlodash for dates‚Äù that‚Äôs packed with over 200 date and time manipulation functions, but it continues to get updates and a v3 is on the way. GitHub repo. Sasha Koss
Chart.js 4.3: Canvas-Based Charts for the Web ‚Äî One of those libraries that feels like it‚Äôs been there forever but still looks fresh and continues to get good updates. Bar, line, area, bubble, pie, fonut, scatter, and radar charts are all a piece of cake to render. Samples and GitHub repo. Chart.js Contributors
Beautiful Security and License Compliance Reports for Your App‚Äôs Dependencies ‚Äî Free & Open Source: Try the Better NPM Audit for Your App Now. Sandworm‚Ä§dev sponsor
Axios 1.4: Promise-Based HTTP Client for Browser and Node ‚Äî A long standing project and still getting frequent updates despite rapidly being seen as the 'jQuery of HTTP request libraries.' If you need it, you‚Äôll know. Matt Zabriskie
Marked.js 5.0: A Fast Markdown Parser and Compiler ‚Äî A low-level Markdown compiler built for speed and available as a client-side library, server-side library, and even a CLI. v5.0 deprecates some options in favor of using external plugins. Here‚Äôs a live demo. Christopher Jeffrey
Mock Service Worker 1.2: REST/GraphQL API Mocking Library ‚Äî Intercepts requests which you can then mock. Capture outgoing requests using an Express-like routing syntax, complete with parameters, wildcards, and regexes. GitHub repo. Artem Zakharchenko
The Fastest JavaScript Data Grid Component Bryntum Grid sponsor
Pretty TypeScript Errors: Make Errors Prettier and Human-Readable in VS Code Yoav Balasiano
next-sitemap: Sitemap Generator for Next.js Apps Vishnu Sankar

Team Lead Web Development ‚Äî Experienced with Node, React, and TS? Join us and lead a motivated team of devs and help grow and shape the future of our web app focused on helping millions explore the outdoors.

QUICK RELEASES: Tremor 2.4 ‚Äì React library to build dashboards. oclif 3.9 ‚Äì Node.js CLI app framework. github-script 2.1 ‚Äì GitHub Actions workflows in JS. Highlight.js 11.8 ‚Äì Syntax highlighter. Plotly.js 2.22 ‚Äì Data visualization library. ngx-stripe 16.0 ‚Äì Angular wrapper for Stripe Elements.
üó£ A quick word from Angular's Minko Gechev
When Minko reached out to remind us of the Angular v16 launch, we decided we'd remind him that most JavaScript Weekly readers aren't using Angular (sorry Minko!) but to ask if he'd like to make the case as to why JavaScript developers shouldn't sleep on Angular in 2023. Here's what he had to say:
The problem in the JavaScript ecosystem we're solving with Angular is to provide a reliable, integrated solution that gives you all the core libraries and tools you need to focus on building apps, rather than fixing incompatible dependencies/API changes, etc. I understand that's what most technologies claim, the difference with Angular is that:
We're testing all core modules such as framework, router, forms, etc. on over 4,000 Google projects on every commit to guarantee stability and integration. We're sharing updates in a predictable release schedule (twice a year) where we evolve everyone via the same mechanism we use to keep every project at Google to the HEAD commit on the main branch on GitHub. It's integrated as part of the ng update command of the CLI. With the recent updates we've been: Catching up with some of the use cases we were missing. Advancing the performance and developer experience, while setting the foundation for more advancements throughout 2023 and 2024. On the second point, we're expecting lots of more improvements in reactivity and SSR in the next 12 months.
So there you have it.
